newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian T-bills open stronger ahead of auction.
newsitem.headline: Canadian T-bills open stronger ahead of auction.

text.p: Canadian T-bills opened stronger on Tuesday with a firmer U.S. fixed-income market and steady Canadian dollar helping to encourage buying ahead of today's auction, dealers said.

"Generally, it's a little more positive tone in the U.S.," said one T-bill trader with a bank-owned brokerage. "We have seen some pretty good account buying, not a lot in the longer terms, but certainly in three to six month area there's some very good buying."
Canada's three-month when-issued T-bill firmed to yield 2.95 percent from 2.99 percent at Monday's close.
The Bank of Canada this afternoon will auction C$4.4 billion of three-month, six-month and one-year T-bills. Results of the weekly auction will be released at 1315 EDT/1715 GMT.
Dealers said there should be solid interest in the auction assuming the market does not rally much further ahead of it.
"We have to be careful. If we start rallying into it then it kind of changes it around, but we think the levels are pretty good," the dealer said.
In other prices, the six-month when-issued T-bill firmed to yield of 3.31 percent from 3.34 percent. The one-year T-bill firmed to yield 3.78 percent from 3.83 percent.
The call loan or overnight lending rate traded at 3.0 percent, the center of the Bank of Canada's 2.75-3.25 percent target range.
